questions.question: When does the first segment of the take-off climb begin?

questions.question: A headwind component:
What is the effect of an increase in pressure altitude?

(b) Decreased take-off distance and increased performance
(c) Increased take-off distance and decreased performance
(d) Decreased take-off distance with decreased performance
questions.solution: (a) Increased take-off distance with increased performance

questions.question: What affects endurance?
options: (c) Speed, weight and fuel on board

questions.question: What degrades aircraft performance?

(b) High altitude, high temperature, high humidity
(c) Low altitude, high temperature, low humidity
(d) High temperature, high altitude, low humidity
questions.solution: (a) Low altitude, low temperature, low humidity

questions.question: If your take-off is limited by the climb limit mass, what is the effect of a headwind?

(c) the distance from brakes release to a point on the ground below which the
(d) the distance from brakes release to a point half way between where the

questions.question: Which of the following combinations most reduces the take-off and climb
Density altitude is:

questions.solution: (a) the true altitude of the aircraft

questions.question: The take-off climb gradient:
options: (a) increases in a headwind and decreases in a tailwind
(b) decreases in a headwind and increases in a tailwind
(c) is independent of the wind component
(d) is determined with the aircraft in the take-off configuration
questions.solution: (a) increases in a headwind and decreases in a tailwind

questions.question: The effect of changing altitude on the maximum rate of climb (ROC) and speed
options: (a) as altitude increases the ROC and speed both decrease
(b) as altitude increases the ROC and speed both increase
(c) as altitude increases the ROC decreases but the speed remains constant
(d) as altitude increases the ROC remains constant but the speed increases
questions.solution: (a) as altitude increases the ROC and speed both decrease

questions.question: A runway at an aerodrome has a declared take-off run of 3000 m with 2000 m of
An aircraft may use either 5° or 15° flap setting for take-off.  The effect of selecting

(b) take-off distance and take-off climb gradient will both decrease
(c) take-off distance will increase and take-off climb gradient will decrease
(d) take-off distance will decrease and take-off climb gradient will increase
questions.solution: (a) take-off distance and take-off climb gradient will both increase

questions.question: The use of reduced thrust for take-off is permitted:

questions.solution: (a) if the field length limited take-off mass is greater than the climb limited take-

questions.question: Planning the performance for a runway with no obstacles, it is found that the climb

questions.question: A turbojet is in a climb at a constant IAS. What happens to the drag?

(b) will require a greater take-off distance and have a lower climb gradient
(c) will require a shorter take-off distance and have a lower climb gradient

questions.solution: (a) decreases as altitude increases and weight decreases

questions.question: A higher mass at a given altitude will reduce the gradient of climb and the rate of

questions.solution: (a) independent of the centre of gravity (C of G)

questions.question: Concerning maximum range in a turbojet aircraft, which of the following is true?

(c) To achieve maximum range speed should be decreased in a headwind and
(d) The change in speed required to achieve maximum range is dependent on the
questions.solution: (a) The speed to achieve maximum range is not affected by the wind component

questions.question: For a turbojet aircraft what is the reason for the use of maximum range speed?
Why are step climbs used on long range flights in jet transport aircraft?
options: (a) To comply with ATC flight level constraints
(b) Step climbs have no significance for jet aircraft, they are used by piston aircraft
(c) To fly as close as possible to the optimum altitude as mass reduces
(d) They are only justified if the actual wind conditions differ significantly from
questions.solution: (a) To comply with ATC flight level constraints

questions.question: The absolute ceiling of an aircraft is:
options: (a) where the rate of climb reaches a specified value
(b) always lower than the aerodynamic ceiling
(c) where the rate of climb is theoretically zero
(d) where the gradient of climb is 5%
questions.solution: (a) where the rate of climb reaches a specified value
